vehicle.name: Mitsubishi MUTII MMC 1G DSM OBDI - EFI

DataListItem.Notes: Displays state of the throttle. High voltage or % value means a more open throttle. When logging engine activity (especially on the dyno), it is useful to log throttle position. This makes it easy to see when a power run begins and ends i.e. when the driver's foot is depressing the accelerator fully. Some mitsubishis show up to 20% when your foot is off the accelerator, and will show a max of 90-99% when your foot is fully applied, this is normal. In Spec: 0.535 âˆ’ 0.735 V would translate as 0.535/5.0V= 10.7 to 14.7 at Idle, if its not then unscrew and move your tps until it does.
No Response from Vehicle ECU

Long Term Fuel Trim - Low, now represented in terms of a percentage. make sure you are within the 5% band, because outside of 5% you should rescale your injectors.
Old Formula: 0.78125*x

Long Term Fuel Trim - Mid make sure you are within the 5% band, because outside of 5% you should rescale your injectors.
Old Formula: 0.78125*x

Long Term Fuel Trim - High make sure you are within the 5% band, because outside of 5% you should rescale your injectors.
Old Formula: 0.78125*x

Long Term Fuel Trim - High make sure you are within the 5% band, because outside of 5% you should rescale your injectors.
Old Formula: 0.78125*x

Short Term Fuel Trim - When the fuelling is under closed loop control by the lambda sensor(s), this refers to the amount of fuel added or subtracted from the value retrieved from the fuel map. -5% would mean that the ecu is fuelling 5% less than the map says in order to achieve the ideal air/fuel ratio. Under high loads, the ECU switches off closed loop control, and uses values from the map. At this point, you will see AFC drop to 0%. This is why it is important that fuelling mapping is accurate (or at least rich) at high loads - the ECU does not compensate for errors here. Old Formula: 0.78125*x
No Response from Vehicle ECU

Measured voltage from the car battery. May be as low as 10 Volts when ignition is off. Should rise to around 14-15 Volts when the engine is running. If you see less than 12 volts when the engine is running, then you will need to get your Alternator looked at.

Not available on all Mitsubishis, generally only those from 1998 onwards allow the speed to be logged from the EFI ecu, see the ABS ecu if you wish to log vehicle speed on earlier vehicles. For UK Vehicles, select 'U.K. Vehicle speed correction' from the Logging menu above, this is because the UK mitsubishis use a US ecu with a piggyback speed converter. So it applies a further calculation to bring it back to MPH/KPH as required.
Speed of wheel rotation in kilometres per hour/miles per hour for standard wheel circumference. Data value may not be updated as frequently as engine speed(RPM), hence acceleration times may be more accurately determined from engine speed(RPM). This value may not be accurate if the car wheels or gears have been changed from standard, since this changes the rolling circumference.
For UK Vehicles, use the UK Logging option under the Logging menu, or use these functions: KPH = 3.218688*x MPH = 2*x

Load 1 Byte (Load1B) is only available if you are running a Tephra Modified ecu rom. Check the tuning guide on www.evoscan.com on how to do this. This Load value is calculated by the ecu internally, and is based on AirFlow (MAF) Sensor and Crankshaft Position Sensor (RPM), i.e. more air flow and less crankshaft speed will give you higher Load values. i.e. going up a steep hill with your foot to the floor. Load is effectively similiar to this calculation: (current airflow / peak airflow) * (Baro And AirTemp Compensation) * 100%.
Load1B doesnt use the injector scaling value on the main evoscan screen, this value is already available internally to the ecu code.
Knock Sum counter from the knock sensor, accurate for 1998+ Mitsubishi vehicles. use KnockSum3E for older mitsubishi knock sum readings.

This value is great for 1998 to 2007 Mitsubishi vehicles. For pre1997 mitsi use Coolant Temp. Temperature of the radiator coolant water. Expect to see around 85degC - 95degC from a warmed up engine. Don't work the engine too hard until the temperature is at least 80 degrees. During racetrack use you will regularly see up to 110-115DegC. If the coolant temp goes this high, ensure you leave the key on, but not running, for 5 minutes after you have stopped to keep the fan flowing over the radiator and engine block. Anything over 120degC is going to be of a major concern, and can indicate a radiator water leak, a water pump leak, or a blown headgasket.

This requires a Wideband sensor device to be connected via the SerialPort/Comport or via a FTDI USB to RS232 SerialPort adapter. Use the Wideband menu above to select the correct external wideband you are using. If you are getting ComPort errors, untick this item, to ascertain if the wideband is the problem.

This value is calculated in EvoScan, ensure you select Injector Pulse Width if you want to get this Duty Cycle percentage. Ensure IPW is a checked item in the list above this item, if you have the Injector Pulse Width after the IDC, it wont log IDC, they have to be in the correct order.
Injector duty cycle % , which is RPM * 'Injector ms' / 1200. If you are regularly seeing over 90% duty, you may need bigger injectors. The injectors must have enough 'head room' too cope with unexpectedly high air flows - these may be caused by overboost, faults and particularly cold weather.

[RPM]*[InjPulseWidth]*20*6/[Speed]/1200
NaN = Not a Number. i.e. when Speed is 0, then the calculation will divide by zero and will display NaN.

Manifold Absolute & Relative Pressure This is boost pressure, and may be represented as absolute or relative, depending on the ECU - some ECUs report both parameters, whilst some only report one. Absolute pressure in the manifold is relative to a vacuum. Subtract approx 14.5 PSI to get relative pressure. When boost pressure in the manifold is shown as relative to atmospheric pressure, negative values represent partial vacuums in the manifold.

For 1998+ Mitsubishi, use MAF Air Temp Scaled. Temperature of air drawn into the engine for combustion. Generally measured at the point of entry to the air filter. This will not give an indication of charge temperature. However intake temperature is useful to the ECU for determination of the wastegate duty cycle required to produce a given boost pressure. High boost pressures may be attained with lower wastegate duty cycles when the IAT is low.
This value is great for 1998 to 2007 Mitsubishi vehicles. For pre1997 mitsi use Air Temperature.
Connect a Zeitronix Wideband ZT2 or ZT3 device to your laptop to get this reading.

Connect a Zeitronix Wideband ZT2 or ZT3 device to your laptop to get this reading. EGT is not a standard sensor normally included on the Mitsubishi vehicles, it is drilled into the exhaust manifold near one of the end cylinders to measure exhaust temps. Measuring this will help ensure piston melt down doesn't occur, which can happen within 3 seconds under lean conditions, high knock, high egt temps, and high rpms.

At sea level, this should be around 100kpa. On some vehicles, the value is not updated continuously, since a single pressure sensor is shared for reading both manifold and atmospheric pressures, a solenoid being using to switch the input to the sensor.

The rate of flow of air into the engine. Some ECUs report air flow voltage, whilst others report a calculated flow rate. The voltage from which the ecu calculates mass air flow is non-linear, with smaller changes in output voltage being seen for flow changes at high rates compared with low flow rates. It is from mass air flow that the ECU calculates engine load which has a big influence on ignition timing and fuelling.

These parameters report the output voltage of the O2 sensors. Early vehicles tend to have a single 'Front O2 Sensor', whereas newer vehicles have both a 'Front A/F Sensor' and a 'Rear O2 Sensor'. These sensors do not report an accurate air/fuel ratio, but instead provide a rich/lean signal to the ECU. Their output voltages switches sharply as the AFR crosses the stoichiometric ratio. Values of approx 0 to 0.9 Volts are normal. 0 being lean, 0.9 being very rich. The sensor voltage will oscillate between these extremes when under closed loop control. Under high loads, the voltage should never drop below 0.7 Volts. If it does, this means that the fuel mixture is too lean when on boost. Quite possibly there is a fault with the air flow sensor.
The addition of cone style induction kits, whilst improving top end power and throttle response is known to upset air/fuel ratios. Alteration of the ecu calibration (AKA a remap) is the solution.

When the vehicle is at Idle, this is the value the ECU will try and target. It will show higher values at colder tempereratures i.e 1250rpm, and 750 after the car has warmed up. Generally the ECU adds 50-150rpm to the Target RPM when the Air Conditioner is turned on to counter-act the slight extra load in the engine from the a/c compressor.

These parameters report the output voltage of the O2 sensors. Early vehicles tend to have a single 'Front O2 Sensor', whereas newer vehicles have both a 'Front A/F Sensor' and a 'Rear O2 Sensor'. These sensors do not report an accurate air/fuel ratio, but instead provide a rich/lean signal to the ECU. Their output voltages switches sharply as the AFR crosses the stoichiometric ratio. Values of approx 0 to 0.9 Volts are normal. 0 being lean, 0.9 being very rich. The sensor voltage will oscillate between these extremes when under closed loop control. Under high loads, the voltage should never drop below 0.7 Volts. If it does, this means that the fuel mixture is too lean when on boost. Quite possibly there is a fault with the air flow sensor.
The addition of cone style induction kits, whilst improving top end power and throttle response is known to upset air/fuel ratios. Alteration of the ecu calibration (AKA a remap) is the solution.

RPM/Speed=Gear
Using this value you should be able to tell which gear it is for your vehicle, it is a raw RPM divided by Speed value because each vehicle can have different gear ratios.
if you get NaN, this means speed is Zero, and you can't divide by zero. NaN stands for Not a Number.

This is an internal Mitsubishi ECU calculated value that determines how much air volume is used in the cylinders. It is based primarily calculated from the MAF Sensor (Mass Airflow Intake Sensor) and RPM

Japan domestic market import mitsubishi vehicles Manifold Absolute & Relative Pressure. This is boost pressure, and may be represented as absolute or relative, depending on the ECU - some ECUs report both parameters, whilst some only report one. Absolute pressure in the manifold is relative to a vacuum. Subtract approx 14.5 PSI to get relative pressure. When boost pressure in the manifold is shown as relative to atmospheric pressure, negative values represent partial vacuums in the manifold.
MAP sensors do not know the local atmospheric pressure. To log boost in psig (what all boost gauges show and what people always use to discuss boost values), the conversion formula for the logging program needs to have an offset for your local atmospheric pressure. The general formula for the JDM Evo 9 MAP sensor is:
0.19347*x-b
where b is the local atmospheric pressure. The local atmospheric pressure is affected strongly affected by altitude. For example the pressure at sea level is 14.7 psi, but at 5000 ft, the pressure is 12.2 psi. That's a pretty big difference when you want to log boost. Use this table of altitude vs pressure to determine the offset pressure for your formula:
altitude (ft) local atmospheric pressure (psi) 0 14.7 500 14.4 1000 14.2 1500 13.9 2000 13.7 2500 13.4 3000 13.2 3500 12.9 4000 12.7 4500 12.5 5000 12.2 6000 11.8 7000 11.3 8000 10.9
*For example*, if you are living at 750 ft, then you'd want to use 14.3 psi as your offset, and the formula would be
0.19347*x-14.3
This is the Knock Sum reading used on 1995-1997 Mitsubishi. It uses the 3E command to get the MUT reading.

Idle Stepper Controller used for letting air past your air intake throttle valve so that the engine can idle whilst your foot is off the accelerator. sometimes known as ISV. See the Evo manual on the evoscan.com website how to tune your idle for better off throttle performance.
This is the actual target AFR value used by the ECU. It is shown in the ECU Rom table settings map called High and Low Octane Fuel that contains AFRMAP values by Load and RPM.

This is just an extended calculation to formulate the real Load value beyond that shown in ECULoad. A more accurate method is to reflash your ecu with a ROM mod that allows you to log Load1Byte (Load1B)
For Load calculated dont forget to update the InjectorScaling on the Main Form, with your injector scaling value used for your rom.
5*InjScaling*([InjPulseWidth]-(-0.1026*[Battery]+1.8741))/[AFRMAP]
just another load reading, not really used. Load1B is the most useful and only load reading required for tuning.

clips at 160 due to vehicle ecu internal calculation (5*255/8) and you can only fit the numbers 0 to 255 in 1 byte being returned from the ecu to evoscan during datalogging. Best to install a Tephramod rom, and utilise Load1B instead.
Total Latency is Injector_Latency_Base*Inj_batt_volt_latecy_compensat(v) /4
Depreciated now, use Load1Byte instead, it has faster updates. Load MUT 2Byte will only work if you have reflashed tephra mod rom to your Evo ECU via EcuFlash and an EvoScan Openport 1.3U USB Cable.

Depreciated now, (use RPM instead, it has faster updates). RPM MUT 2Byte will only work if you have reflashed tephra mod rom to your Evo ECU via EcuFlash and an EvoScan Openport 1.3U USB Cable. This value will allow display of rpms over 8,000rpm (31.25*255)

Airflow is good to see the MAF sensor activity as calculated by the ECU by RPM. MUT 2Byte Mod is a reflashed modification to the ECU via EcuFlash and an EvoScan Reprogramming USB Cable. This value will allow display of AirFlow over 1600hz (6.25*255)

The Octane Level will start at 100% and decrease if there is persistant knock sum present. the Octane Level % is used as part of adjustment to the Timing to help protect the engine from excessive knock, normally caused by lean fuel conditions (excessive heat), or bad octane fuel.
Exhaust Gas Recirculation Temperature.

Manifold Air Temperature Scaled. This measures the temperature at the intake after the turbo but just before the air enters the engine. The lower the temperature the better for performance. A larger or more efficient intercooler will bring your manifold air temperatures down more. Also EGT, (Exhaust Gas Temps) is another good sensor to monitor. EGT is not a standard sensor on the Mitsubishi vehicles though.
Waste Gate Duty Cycle. Used by the ecu for boost control for those 1998+ vehicles that have a efi ecu controlled boost control solenoid.
Waste Gate Duty Cycle. Used by the ecu to adjust boost control for those 1998+ vehicles that have a efi ecu controlled boost control solenoid.
You can wire in an external sensor into your ecu to get Boost PSI/Bar readings
Manifold Absolute Pressure Scaled. MAP measures the boost pressure at the intake manifold.
Airflow is calculated by maf volts divided by rpm. this value is calculated inside the ecu with a couple of other temperature and barometer variables to give an accurate airflow reading.
You can wire in an external 0-5volt sensor into your ecu to get this value.
You can wire in an external 0-5volt sensor into your ecu to get this value.
This is a development mod,
Only available when using the Zeitronix ZT2/ZT3 2010 model or newer.
Innovate Wideband COMPORT device Readings. WDB must be ticked also.These values still in beta testing. Double check your values are accurate.
Innovate Wideband COMPORT device Readings. WDB must be ticked also.These values still in beta testing. Double check your values are accurate.
Select LC1 Innovate in the wideband menu. WDB item must be ticked also. For TC-4 Cylinder Head Temp change the Eval formula to 0.293255131*x for TC-4 DegC change the Eval formula to 1.06842619*x
Select LC1 Innovate in the wideband menu. WDB item must be ticked also. For TC-4 Cylinder Head Temp change the Eval formula to 0.293255131*x for TC-4 DegC change the Eval formula to 1.06842619*x
Select LC1 Innovate in the wideband menu. WDB item must be ticked also. For TC-4 Cylinder Head Temp change the Eval formula to 0.293255131*x for TC-4 DegC change the Eval formula to 1.06842619*x
Select LC1 Innovate in the wideband menu. WDB item must be ticked also. For TC-4 Cylinder Head Temp change the Eval formula to 0.293255131*x for TC-4 DegC change the Eval formula to 1.06842619*x
Select LC1 Innovate in the wideband menu. WDB item must be ticked also. For TC-4 Cylinder Head Temp change the Eval formula to 0.293255131*x for TC-4 DegC change the Eval formula to 1.06842619*x
This is a development mod, that when flashed to an ecu allows you to log any RAM value from ecu memory. This development is still work in progress.
This is a development mod, that when flashed to an ecu allows you to log any RAM value from ecu memory. This development is still work in progress.
This is the raw knock sensor voltage as seen by the vehicle ecu. Also see Knock Sum for a more useful and user friendly item to log for determining knock.
DataItem RequestID 72 contains some bit flags for knock
If ticked, this will continually reset MUTII EFI Diagnostic Trouble Codes. Only supported by Mitsubishi vehicles 1994-1998

Connect an external USB DLP-IO8 Device to your laptop usb port. It supports 0-5volt Analogue to Digital, 8 channels. DLP-IO8 devices also works with the EvoScan GPSNav Standalone Display Unit. Each of the 8 DLP ports can be either Digital Input, or Analogue Input, or Temperature Input, or Digital output for switching relays.

Connect an external USB DLP-IO8 Device to your laptop usb port. It supports 0-5volt Analogue to Digital, 8 channels. DLP-IO8 devices also works with the EvoScan GPSNav Standalone Display Unit. Each of the 8 DLP ports can be either Digital Input, or Analogue Input, or Temperature Input, or Digital output for switching relays.

Actual Temperature eval formula not yet known. I still have to get hold of a temp sensor for it. Connect an external USB DLP-IO8 Device to your laptop usb port. It supports 8 channels. DLP-IO8 devices also works with the EvoScan GPSNav Standalone Display Unit.
